content: Act as a helpful AI assistant

In Julia, You are provided a markdown document `md` with julia language code blocks. Write a function `extract_julia_code` that extracts all the code blocks, removes code fences and joins the code blocks (if there are multiple) together with a newline. Return a String. Do not provide any examples.

Certainly! Below is a function in Julia that will extract all Julia code blocks from a markdown document, remove the code fences, and join the code blocks together with a newline:

```julia
function extract_julia_code(md::String)
    # Define the start and end patterns for Julia code blocks in markdown
    start_pattern = r"^```julia\s*$"
    end_pattern = r"^```\s*$"

    # Split the markdown document into lines
    lines = split(md, '\n')

    # Initialize an empty array to hold the code blocks
    code_blocks = []
    inside_code_block = false
    current_block = []

    # Iterate over each line in the markdown document
    for line in lines
        # Check if the line is the start of a Julia code block
        if occursin(start_pattern, line)
            inside_code_block = true
            continue
        end
        # Check if the line is the end of a code block
        if occursin(end_pattern, line)
            inside_code_block = false
            # Add the current block to the list of code blocks
            push!(code_blocks, join(current_block, '\n'))
            # Reset the current block
            current_block = []
            continue
        end
        # If we are inside a code block, add the line to the current block
        if inside_code_block
            push!(current_block, line)
        end
    end

    # Join all the code blocks with a newline and return the result
    return join(code_blocks, '\n')
end
```

This function will process the markdown string `md`, extract the Julia code blocks, and return them as a single string with each block separated by a newline. It uses regular expressions to identify the start and end of the code blocks and assumes that the code blocks are fenced with triple backticks followed by the language identifier `julia`.
